data.text: Contents
Introduction

The wound healing process is a complex sequence of events, and many wounds heal without any complications. However, for chronic, non-healing or hard to heal wounds (for example pressure ulcers, complex leg ulcers, non-healing surgical wounds, diabetic foot ulcers), the healing process is interrupted, and the normal progress towards healing is stalled. These wounds are often characterised by the presence of large quantities of necrotic, sloughy or infected tissue within the wound bed. This tissue delays healing, can harbour bacteria with potential for local or systemic infection with risk of sepsis, and prevents accurate wound assessment by obscuring the extent of tissue destruction. Where clinically appropriate this tissue must be debrided (removed).
If urgent and rapid debridement is required, and surgical intervention is not an option, larval therapy can be considered as a viable option.

If Larval Therapy is prescribed as part of a patient's wound management regime, it is essential that a structured, well documented care plan is in place setting out clear concise instructions including wound review, and wound evaluation dates and is adhered to. This will ensure the patient receives appropriate wound management throughout the duration of this therapy, and reduce the likelihood of any wound related complications. This in turn will facilitate the best potential healing outcomes for the patient.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
To set minimum safety standards for Registered Nurses and Midwives, and Medical personnel who may be required to care for a patient who requires the use of Larval Therapy
To describe minimum standard for patient records.
To ensure local governance requirements are met
Definitions

table_items.text: Involves the use of the larvae of the green bottle fly (Lucilia Sericata) which feed on dead tissue, debris and microbes. They work by liquefying devitalised tissue; they do this by producing secretions that break down the dead tissue into semi liquid form which they are able to ingest. They do not feed on living tissue. They also cannot dig, tunnel or burrow into healthy tissue. They have an antibacterial effect by ingesting any bacteria, fungi or viruses that are in the liquefied tissue; this action reduces the bioburden in the wound and can help prevent biofilm forming in the wound.

Removal of devitalised or infected tissue, fibrin or foreign material from a wound (‘debris). This can be removed by the body through the natural wound healing process. However wound healing can be delayed if there are large amounts of debris within the wound which can also provide an environment for infection.

Larvae are only available for application in a Biobag; this is a finely woven, heat-sealed pouch which contains a small piece(s) of foam to protect the larvae at the start of the treatment. The larvae are contained and sealed with the BioBag, where they remain throughout the treatment process.

Standard of practice
This SOP only covers the care of a patient undergoing Larval therapy as a treatment regime as part of their complex wound management.
Other aspects of wound management care will be covered by the Wound Management policy.
Information relating to the patient and their presenting problem is collated in accordance with standards set by the practitioner's professional organisation.
Information relating to treatment options is identified based on the best available evidence in accordance with standards set by the practitioner's professional organisation.
Patients will be individually assessed by an appropriately registered practitioner to ensure it is appropriate to use Larval Therapy as part of the wound debridement process.
The Tissue Viability Team should be contacted:
To inform the Team or request advice from the Team before Larval Therapy is commenced
If any wound related concerns are identified during the treatment such as uncontrolled patient pain or active bleeding
If the wound is not responding to the therapy.
The Tissue Viability Team can be contacted via bleep:
Southend site:  bleep 1127 Basildon site:  bleep 1112 Broomfield site:  bleep 6555 / 2517
Process

The aim of using Larval Therapy is to rapidly remove devitalised tissue from the wound bed in order to achieve a clean healthy granulating wound that is prepared and ready to receive products and treatments that will support on-going wound healing.

Before considering Larval Therapy, a holistic patient assessment must be undertaken. This is essential to ensure use of Larval Therapy is appropriate and that there are no contra-indications to using the therapy. This assessment should be undertaken by a Registered Nurse, Tissue Viability Nurse or Doctor who has received training / instruction on safe effective use of Larval Therapy and management of a patient receiving this therapy.

table_items.text: To ensure patient agreement to, and understanding of the treatment

Thorough wound assessment to determine the nature of the wound bed. This must include: Wound measurements maximum length, width and depth of the wound in centimetres (cm) Tissue type present in the wound and % of this tissue present Any signs of wound infection Condition of surrounding skin Medical photographyon initial assessment and on change of presentation, if appropriate to do so, or as soon as clinically appropriate to do so
In order to obtain and document baseline data. This will enable clinicians to assess wound progress in line with endpoint / goal set for the patient
Ability to offload pressure throughout the duration of the treatment to avoid suffocating the larvae (including on a dynamic mattress)
To ensure therapy is clinically appropriate
To ensure there are no contraindication to therapy and it remains an appropriate treatment choice
Providing the patient with an information leaflet on Larval Therapy
For the patient to have an easily accessible source of information to refer to as required during the therapy

data.text: Clinical indications and contraindications

If Larval Therapy is considered a viable option for the patient, the clinical indications for, and any contraindications to, commencing Larval Therapy must be identified and clearly documented in the patient's clinical record before a decision to proceed with the treatment is taken. Any challenges, risks, or interactions with any other therapies, products or treatments must also be identified, considered, addressed and documented before proceeding.

table_items.text: non-healing or infected wounds to help wound progression from inflammation to proliferation to reduce odour and exudate levels even if healing is not the intended outcome treatment for infected wounds or to prevent infection by removing bioburden. Wound types where Larval Therapy may be used (may require MDT approach. This should be clarified before commencing therapy): : Diabetic ulcers Venous ulcers

data.text: Arterial/ischaemic ulcers
Mixed arterial–venous ulcer (can be used under a non- occlusive compression bandage system up to 40 mm Hg)
Pressure ulcers
Post–traumatic wounds/ulcers, i.e. haematomas
Necrotising fasciitis only following thorough assessment and surgical intervention has been excluded
Pilonidal sinus post-surgery (with extreme caution and under medical supervision)
Non–healing surgical wound
MRSA–infected wound

table_items.text: Must not be used on: wounds that have a tendency to bleed, or wounds close to an exposed major blood vessel, especially if considered to be necrotic. unexplored sinus wounds or known fistulas that could lead to an exposed organ. Should not be used on: wounds with dry necrotic eschar (rehydration is required in the first instance). a patient whose clotting is deranged. Can be used on: suspected necrotising fasciitis but only once a thorough assessment has been carried out and surgical intervention rejected or as an adjunct to surgery
use with caution on wounds over adjacent exposed organs or leading to a body cavity, and only under the close supervision of the doctor or nurse responsible for the patient
Potential increased pain at the wound site (particularly in wounds where pain is
present prior to applying Larval Therapy, and some wounds with an ischemic
component). Review pain control pre-application and during treatment.
If pain is severe remove the larvae and irrigate the wound bed to alleviate the
Discuss simultaneous treatment with systemic cytostatic /cytotoxic substances
with the patient's Medical / Surgical team before treatment is undertaken
Avoid use of all topical treatments, as they may impact negatively on larvae
viability and effectiveness and therefore treatment outcome.
Remove any topical residues prior to applying the larvae by irrigating the wound
There may be changes to the wound which include dark red or brown discharge

data.text: and an odour (especially with a build-up of dead tissue). These changes may occur due to larvae activity.
Make sure secondary dressings are not too tight or occlusive as this will reduce the larval viability
There is no known interaction from radiation. Larval Therapy does not have to be removed before x-ray, MRI, CT etc. unless the dressing will interfere with the procedure.

data.text: Using laval therapy

table_items.text: Available in 5 different sizes. Size guide is set out in Appendix 1. Appropriate selection depends on: Size of wound: length, width and depth In order for treatment to be effective the BioBag must cover and have direct contact with the surface. If using more than 1 bag they must not be overlapped. BioBags edges can be folded if too big for the wound.

Larvae are to be prescribed on the inpatient medication chart prior to administration It should be prescribed as a stat dose on the scheduled start day, selecting according to the dressing size as follows: LARVAE BIOBAG 2.5cm x 4cm (Unlicensed) LARVAE BIOBAG 5cm x 4cm (Unlicensed) LARVAE BIOBAG 5cm x 6cm (Unlicensed) LARVAE BIOBAG 12cm x 6cm (Unlicensed) LARVAE BIOBAG 10cm x 10cm (Unlicensed) Larvae should be signed for by the administering nurse in line with the Trust Administration of Medication Policy

data.text: Ordering Larvae

data.url: MSESOP-21012 Safe and effective use of larvae therapy SOP 1.1.003.png

data.text: Use the size guide (Appendix 1) to select the size and number of BioBags required
The treatment must be prescribed for the patient before ordering can take place.

Once prescribed, orders must reach pharmacy by  midday. This may be done via the ward pharmacy team or directly to the pharmacy procurement team by the requesting registered nurse. All information required for the order must be provided (see below).
Only the Pharmacy procurement team are permitted to order larvae. They will contact BioMonde (0345 230 1810) providing the following information:
Size and quantity of BioBag dressing
Official order number
Intended delivery date
Full delivery address (all deliveries must be signed for)
Invoice address
Name and/or the GMC/NMC number of the prescriber
Orders can be accepted by BioMonde up to 2pm the day before the intended application date
Delivery is available Monday to Saturday.
Ordering codes

table_items.text: Keep in the transit containers until application Store at a temperature of 6 C to 25 C (products must not be refrigerated) Apply by the expiry date for optimal results (generally up to midnight the day after delivery)

BioBags can be left in place for a maximum of four days, depending on the wound environment and the progress of the treatment. (the day of application is day 0) Treatment can be repeated with a fresh BioBag, if the wound is not completely clean within four days. There is no limit on the number of treatments needed but successful debridement is usually achieved in two-three applications.

data.text: Wound management
Treatment must be undertaken in a clean and private environment with adequate washing facilities nearby.
A gown, towel or other cover should be provided to maintain the patient's privacy and dignity.
The practitioner washes their hands before and after the procedure.
The practitioner uses a sterile wound dressing technique.
Refer to the Treatment pathway for the use of Larval Therapy (Appendix 2)
Pre-assessment
To carry out this procedure you will need the following:

table_items.text: Sachet normal saline for irrigating the wound or dressing residue and moistening of primary swab.
Correct size BioBag– single or combination of sizes depending on wound size
Zinc based barrier cream or hydrocolloid to protect intact peri-wound skin (Sudocrem)
An absorbent (non-occlusive) dressing pad and a lightweight retention bandage, tape or compression

data.text: Using larvae therapy

table_items.text: Caring for the larvae – Application instructions
Remove the BioBag from the transport vial Check that the larvae are alive if any concerns contact the BioMonde helpdesk (see Appendix 3)

data.text: Place BioBag on to the wound and overlap onto the wound margins.
When applying place a moistened gauze swab over the BioBag to ensure the larvae are dampened (especially if the wound is very dry). Repeat this at each dressing change
Apply an absorbent outer dressing, to manage increased exudate and maintain a non- occlusive environment for the larvae.
Secure all dressings in place by taping outer edges of the absorbent dressing or apply a light bandage.
Dressings:
Only use plain cotton breathable absorbent surgical wound pads.
Do not use: foams, films, super-absorbent or absorbent pads or any dressings that wick fluid away from the wound or retain exudate in the dressing by any method

table_items.text: duration of the treatment on the larvae; this includes lying against an air mattress, as the larvae will suffocate (short periods of pressure only for the purpose of mobilising or turning) Check larvae are viable at changes of secondary dressing – movement of larvae and presence of dark red/brown exudate are indications that larvae are alive. If the patient complains of pain and discomfort – reassess and consider appropriateness of continuing the therapy Assess the necessity for any subsequent application 24 hours before the end of treatment
Discontinue treatment : once the wound is suitably debrided, or if no progress can be observed after three or more applications.

Removal Remove BioBag from the wound using a clean technique Double-bag and dispose of as standard clinical waste, according to Trust policy. After removal the wound does not need to be cleaned / irrigated as the benefit of the larval secretions on the wound will remain. Disposal Regard used larvae products and ancillary dressings as potentially contaminated and dispose of as clinical waste in line with the Trust's infection control policy.
If the patients dies unexpectedly whilst receiving Larval Therapy, remove the larvae from the wound prior to transferring the patient to the mortuary and dispose of the larvae as described above.

data.text: Training requirements

Clinicians ordering, applying and participating in wound care for a patient undergoing Larval Therapy must have received training and instruction on the safe and effective use of Larval Therapy before treatment is commenced. This is either provided by the on-site Tissue Viability Team, or BioMonde clinical support team via the Clinical Helpline: 0345 230 6806
The Ward should keep a training record of staff who attended training on the system.
